description: Telecommunications customer churn dataset containing telephony account features and usage patterns to predict whether customers will switch providers. Originally used in 'Discovering Knowledge in Data: An Introduction to Data Mining'.

creator.note: Unknown original creator, distributed via PMLB

feature_description.total_day_calls: Total number of calls during day
feature_description.total_eve_calls: Total number of calls during evening
feature_description.total_night_calls: Total number of calls during night
feature_description.number_customer_service_calls: Number of calls to customer service

class_distribution.note: Imbalanced dataset typical of real-world churn scenarios

use_case: Customer retention, churn prediction, targeted marketing, customer lifetime value optimization, proactive retention campaigns
business_context: Retaining existing customers is more cost-effective than acquiring new ones
preprocessing: Features include derived charge amounts from usage, area codes as categorical
performance_considerations: Class imbalance (14% churn rate), need for cost-sensitive learning or resampling techniques
advantages: Real business problem, clear features, actionable insights possible
challenges: Imbalanced classes, temporal aspects not captured, regional variations
research_applications: Binary classification, imbalanced learning, customer analytics, feature importance for business insights
evaluation_metrics: Recall/sensitivity crucial for identifying churners, precision-recall trade-offs, cost-sensitive evaluation
business_value: Even 1% reduction in churn can lead to significant revenue retention

citations.reference: Used in 'Discovering Knowledge in Data: An Introduction to Data Mining' by Daniel T. Larose
